newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bunds to fall whether Bundesbank cuts repo or not.
newsitem.headline: Bunds to fall whether Bundesbank cuts repo or not.

text.p: Bunds face an initial sell-off whether the Bundesbank cuts its repo rate or not on Thursday, analysts and dealers said on Wednesday.
But there was disagreement over whether a cut in the repo -- the central bank's main money market rate -- would be better or worse for Bunds in the medium term than a "rates unchanged" announcement.
Some said an unchanged repo would keep hopes of a future easing intact and may weaken other currencies versus the mark, thereby stoking demand for German debt.
Others said a small cut, of five basis points or 0.05 percentage point, would signal that rates were headed lower and thereby keep investors interested in the German market.
"There will be profit-taking whatever happens tomorrow," said Helmut Kaiser, global markets bond analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Frankfurt.

If the Bundesbank cuts the repo rate, dealers will follow the maxim "buy on the rumour, sell on the fact", Kaiser said. If it holds the rate steady, the resulting disappointment will also provoke selling, he added.

Kaiser said any sell-off would at most push September Bund futures as low as 96.90, a technical support line which was likely to hold. That would be equivalent to a rise in 10-year yields to 6.40 percent from the current level of 6.34 percent.
Peter Kerger, portfolio manager at Credit Suisse Capital Management in Frankfurt, said a decision to keep the repo unchanged could hurt the market.
"Doing nothing may be interpreted as meaning that there will be no more rate cuts," Kerger said. "A five basis point cut would be a little more helpful."
In addition, an easing now would help reduce currency market tensions, Kerger said. "If the Bundesbank waits, it may be forced to act later to save other currencies."
Kerger said any initial Bund decline following a rates unchanged announcement would be limited to 20 or 30 basis points.

September Bunds fell sharply, and the mark appreciated, this morning in response to a stronger-than-expected rise in the Ifo institute's business climate index which undermined hopes of an imminent repo easing.
The index for west Germany rose to 94.1 in July from 90.4 in June. Economists had expected a figure of around 91.0.
September Bunds fell as low as 97.45 on the DTB futures exchange, down 0.61 from Tuesday's close, in response to the news.
Dealers said hopes for a slight repo rate cut had been dampened but not dashed.
"We'll see a sell-off in both cases," said Heinz Gunasekera, bond analyst at UBS in Frankfurt.
"But an unchanged rate may be a little bit better for Bunds. There's a chance of currency tension and Bunds would be in favour because of their safe haven status."
Some analysts said the initial sell-off could be quite large because Bunds had risen rapidly in recent weeks.
"A lot of people are overweight in Bunds," Gunasekera said.
Lothar Hessler, bond analyst at Trinkaus & Burkhardt, said a cut would depress the long end of the bond market.
"We'd see a slight rise in yields but nothing serious because the environment for bonds remains favourable. There is no sign of inflation and the economic upturn is modest," Hessler said.
Hessler predicted 10-year German bond yields would rise to 6.50 percent by the end of the year as the economy gradually gained pace.
